metadata.case_name: Workmen of Messrs Hindustan Motors Ltd. v. Hindustan Motors Ltd.

facts.text: The Company was established in 1942, initially assembling motor cars from components imported from foreign countries. Later, manufacture of components started in 1949, gradually increasing until manufacturing more than 70% of components utilised in cars.
At initial stages, Company ran at a loss; Tariff Commission's 1956 Report mentioned loss of Rs. 833 per car on Hindustan Landmaster.
No profit shown and no bonus paid until dispute for 1959-60; dispute for 1959-60 pending, for 1960-61 decided by Tribunal.

For 1960-61, profit and loss account showed net profit of Rs. 249.71 lacs; Rs. 59.53 lacs for ordinary shares dividend (12%), Rs. 27.55 lacs for preference shares (8.57%), total dividends Rs. 87.08 lacs.
Workmen demanded bonus equivalent to six months' wages; monthly wage bill Rs. 4 lacs, total claim Rs. 24 lacs (actual pay Rs. 13.2 lacs after 45% tax refund).
Tribunal calculated surplus Rs. 87.80 lacs without rehabilitation; held Rs. 373.62 lacs needed annually for rehabilitation, exceeding surplus, so no bonus payable.
Company filed statements on rehabilitation: first Schedule IA (31 May 1962) claimed average machinery life 6 years; workmen claimed 30 years; later schedules filed.
Tribunal classified machinery into precision and non-precision based on Income-tax depreciation, inferred different lives; both parties challenge this.
Expert Gerald Waplington: economic life 2-3 to 5-6 years for high accuracy machines; economic life 1/3rd of useful life.
Company engineers Joyce and Bansal: economic life 6-10 years based on 16 hours/day two shifts.
List of discarded machines (Ext. 28, 26 Oct 1962): few from pre-1948, none 1948-1951, minimal 1952-53, mainly 1954-58.
Replacement programme (Ext. 21, March 1960): few pre-1948 machines, majority later.
Ext. 29: prices of old vs recent similar machines; new added for expansion, not replacement.
Machines worked in two shifts until 1959-60, then three shifts.
Depreciation provided: Rs. 325.48 lacs at beginning 1960-61; development rebate reserve Rs. 39.51 lacs; contingencies reserve Rs. 10 lacs; fixed deposits Rs. 220 lacs.
Company claimed all reserves used as working capital per affidavit of Satya Narayan Murarka.

legal_issues.text: Correct application of Full Bench Formula for surplus available for bonus, particularly rehabilitation provision: life of machinery, multiplier for replacement cost, deductions for depreciation and reserves.
Whether to classify machinery into precision/non-precision and use Income-tax depreciation for life.
Correct multipliers for rehabilitation: first/second Schedule IA, reductions for higher production.
Deductions for depreciation and liquid reserves in rehabilitation: when and how to deduct.
Return on reserves and funds used as working capital.

petitioner_arguments.text: Life of machinery should be 30 years as in prior cases like Saxby Farmer.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Saxby Farmer Mazdoor Union v. Ms. Saxby Farmer India Ltd.; Associated Cement Companies Ltd.

petitioner_arguments.text: Use first Schedule IA multipliers only; no average with second; no reduction for higher production.
Deduct depreciation and reserves from earliest blocks requiring replacement.
Return only on reserves used as working capital, not other funds; challenge proof of usage.
Factory buildings life 40 years, non-factory 50 years.

respondent_arguments.text: All machinery economic life 6 years; no classification into precision/non-precision.
Use second Schedule IA higher multipliers; no averaging or reductions.
Deduct depreciation and reserves from total rehabilitation, not earliest blocks; depreciation only if available.
All reserves and surpluses used as working capital per affidavit; entitled to return.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Associated Cement Companies Ltd.; Tara Oil Mills

respondent_arguments.text: Include machinery installed in bonus year for rehabilitation.

court_reasoning.text: Ignore precision/non-precision classification as not claimed by parties; life determined by evidence, not Income-tax depreciation.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Life of machinery varies by factory; must use evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Useful life average 15 years for two shifts (as mostly operated); 25 for one shift, 10 for three shifts. Future divisor on 10 years basis.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence of experts, discards, usage shows 15 years appropriate; coincides with National Engineering case.

court_reasoning.text: Multipliers from first Schedule IA only, proved by Ext. 29; no average with unproved second; no reduction for production as no evidence of appreciable increase.
Deduct depreciation (Rs. 325.48 lacs) and liquid reserves (development rebate Rs. 39.51 lacs) from earliest blocks' replacement cost before annualizing.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Use available resources first for immediate needs; as in Associated Cement.

court_reasoning.text: Include bonus year machinery in rehabilitation with full residuary life.
No change to Tribunal's building lives (factory 25, non-factory 40 years) due to lack of evidence.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No reliable evidence from either side.

court_reasoning.text: Murarka's affidavit insufficient proof all reserves used as working capital; fixed deposits suggest liquidity.

holdings.text: Average useful life of machinery 15 years (two shifts); divisor for future on 10 years (three shifts).
Use first Schedule IA multipliers without averaging or reductions.
Deduct depreciation and available reserves from earliest rehabilitation blocks.
Company's proof on working capital usage inadequate.

statutes_cited.name: Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Tribunal erroneously used for machinery/building life; rejected.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court sets aside Tribunal's award denying bonus; directs recalculation of surplus using corrected Full Bench Formula parameters: machinery life 15 years, specific multipliers, deductions from earliest blocks; remands for fresh computation of bonus payable.
outcome.relief_granted: Remand for recalculation of bonus for 1960-61

key_quotes.text: "the life of the machinery in every case has to be determined in the light of evidence adduced by the parties."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "we think that in this case, it would be appropriate to hold that the average life of the machinery of this Company... may be appropriately taken as 15 years."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "the depreciation and available reserves must be taken into account when calculating the annual provision for rehabilitation required for replacement of the earliest installed machinery."
key_quotes.speaker: court
